title: Blue and white dish with carp

  object_colour: multicoloured

  physical_appearance: This is a Ming dynasty blue-and-white dish. The centre of this large dish depicts a carp leaping out of the waves into the sky; implied by the cloud motifs. The flat rim is decorated with peonies that alternate between a variety of auspicious symbols  common to the Chinese tradition. Its outer body is painted with jasmine flowers. Its lower outer rim has sprawling vine motifs.

  subject_terms_1: carp  Paeonia (genus)  symbolism  flower (motif) repeated motif Taoism

  context_1: It was exhibited at the Exhibition of Chinese Blue-and-White Ceramics held at the National Museum of Singapore in 1978.

  context_8: planners curators

  sgcool_label_text: The centre of this large dish is painted with a carp leaping from waves
 while the flattened rim is decorated with the various auspicious emblems and peony sprays. In Chinese art and culture
 the leaping carp represents determination and accomplishment as it is associated with the passing of the civil service examinations. The imagery stems from a traditional Chinese belief that carps which swim upstream in the Yellow River and leap successfully across the rapids at Dragon’s Gate are transformed into dragons.

metadata.sgcool_label_text: The centre of this large dish is painted with a carp leaping from waves, while the flattened rim is decorated with the various auspicious emblems and peony sprays. In Chinese art and culture, the leaping carp represents determination and accomplishment as it is associated with the passing of the civil service examinations. The imagery stems from a traditional Chinese belief that carps which swim upstream in the Yellow River and leap successfully across the rapids at Dragon’s Gate are transformed into dragons.
